    a01_cdm_reference

    a01_cdm_reference.Rmd
    library(OMOPGenerics)

    The cdm reference

    A cdm reference is a single R object that represents OMOP CDM data. The tables in the cdm reference may be in a database, but a cdm reference may also contain OMOP CDM tables that are in dataframes/tibbles or in arrow. In the latter case the cdm reference would typically be a subset of an original cdm reference that has been derived as part of a particular analysis.

    OMOPGenerics contains the class definition of a cdm reference and a dataframe implementation. For creating a cdm reference using a database, see the CDMConnector package (https://darwin-eu.github.io/CDMConnector/).

    A cdm object can contain three type of tables:

    • Standard tables:
    standardOmopCdmTables()
#>  [1] "person"                "observation_period"    "visit_occurrence"     
#>  [4] "visit_detail"          "condition_occurrence"  "drug_exposure"        
#>  [7] "procedure_occurrence"  "device_exposure"       "measurement"          
#> [10] "observation"           "death"                 "note"                 
#> [13] "note_nlp"              "specimen"              "fact_relationship"    
#> [16] "location"              "care_site"             "provider"             
#> [19] "payer_plan_period"     "cost"                  "drug_era"             
#> [22] "dose_era"              "condition_era"         "metadata"             
#> [25] "cdm_source"            "concept"               "vocabulary"           
#> [28] "domain"                "concept_class"         "concept_relationship" 
#> [31] "relationship"          "concept_synonym"       "concept_ancestor"     
#> [34] "source_to_concept_map" "drug_strength"         "cohort_definition"    
#> [37] "attribute_definition"

    Each one of the tables has a required columns. For example, for the person table this are the required columns:

    requiredOmopCdmColumns(table = "person")
#> [1] "person_id"            "gender_concept_id"    "year_of_birth"       
#> [4] "race_concept_id"      "ethnicity_concept_id"

    • Cohort tables (see generatedCohortSet).

    • Other tables, these other tables can have any format.

    Any table to be part of a cdm object has to fulfill 4 conditions:

    • All must share a common source.

    • The name of the tables must be lowercase.

    • The name of the column names of each table must be lowercase.

    • person and observation_period must be present.

    Required columns 

    #> OMOP CDM version: "5.3"
#> â€¢ person: person_id, gender_concept_id, year_of_birth, race_concept_id,
#>   ethnicity_concept_id
#> â€¢ observation_period: observation_period_id, person_id,
#>   observation_period_start_date, observation_period_end_date,
#>   period_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ attribute_definition: attribute_definition_id, attribute_name,
#>   attribute_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ care_site: care_site_id
#> â€¢ cdm_source: cdm_source_name
#> â€¢ cohort_definition: cohort_definition_id, cohort_definition_name,
#>   definition_type_concept_id, subject_concept_id
#> â€¢ concept: concept_id, concept_name, domain_id, vocabulary_id,
#>   concept_class_id, concept_code, valid_start_date, valid_end_date
#> â€¢ concept_ancestor: ancestor_concept_id, descendant_concept_id,
#>   min_levels_of_separation, max_levels_of_separation
#> â€¢ concept_class: concept_class_id, concept_class_name, concept_class_concept_id
#> â€¢ concept_relationship: concept_id_1, concept_id_2, relationship_id,
#>   valid_start_date, valid_end_date
#> â€¢ concept_synonym: concept_id, concept_synonym_name, language_concept_id
#> â€¢ condition_era: condition_era_id, person_id, condition_concept_id,
#>   condition_era_start_date, condition_era_end_date
#> â€¢ condition_occurrence: condition_occurrence_id, person_id,
#>   condition_concept_id, condition_start_date, condition_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ cost: cost_id, cost_event_id, cost_domain_id, cost_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ death: person_id, death_date
#> â€¢ device_exposure: device_exposure_id, person_id, device_concept_id,
#>   device_exposure_start_date, device_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ domain: domain_id, domain_name, domain_concept_id
#> â€¢ dose_era: dose_era_id, person_id, drug_concept_id, unit_concept_id,
#>   dose_value, dose_era_start_date, dose_era_end_date
#> â€¢ drug_era: drug_era_id, person_id, drug_concept_id, drug_era_start_date,
#>   drug_era_end_date
#> â€¢ drug_exposure: drug_exposure_id, person_id, drug_concept_id,

#> â€¢ drug_strength: drug_concept_id, ingredient_concept_id, valid_start_date,
#>   valid_end_date
#> â€¢ fact_relationship: domain_concept_id_1, fact_id_1, domain_concept_id_2,
#>   fact_id_2, relationship_concept_id
#> â€¢ location: location_id
#> â€¢ measurement: measurement_id, person_id, measurement_concept_id,
#>   measurement_date, measurement_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ metadata: metadata_concept_id, metadata_type_concept_id, name
#> â€¢ note: note_id, person_id, note_date, note_type_concept_id,
#>   note_class_concept_id, note_text, encoding_concept_id, language_concept_id
#> â€¢ note_nlp: note_nlp_id, note_id, lexical_variant, nlp_date
#> â€¢ observation: observation_id, person_id, observation_concept_id,
#>   observation_date, observation_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ payer_plan_period: payer_plan_period_id, person_id,
#>   payer_plan_period_start_date, payer_plan_period_end_date
#> â€¢ procedure_occurrence: procedure_occurrence_id, person_id,
#>   procedure_concept_id, procedure_date, procedure_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ provider: provider_id
#> â€¢ relationship: relationship_id, relationship_name, is_hierarchical,
#>   defines_ancestry, reverse_relationship_id, relationship_concept_id
#> â€¢ source_to_concept_map: source_code, source_concept_id, source_vocabulary_id,
#>   target_concept_id, target_vocabulary_id, valid_start_date, valid_end_date
#> â€¢ specimen: specimen_id, person_id, specimen_concept_id,
#>   specimen_type_concept_id, specimen_date
#> â€¢ visit_detail: visit_detail_id, person_id, visit_detail_concept_id,
#>   visit_detail_start_date, visit_detail_end_date, visit_detail_type_concept_id,
#>   visit_occurrence_id
#> â€¢ visit_occurrence: visit_occurrence_id, person_id, visit_concept_id,
#>   visit_start_date, visit_end_date, visit_type_concept_id
#> â€¢ vocabulary: vocabulary_id, vocabulary_name, vocabulary_reference,
#>   vocabulary_concept_id
    #> OMOP CDM version: "5.4"
#> â€¢ person: person_id, gender_concept_id, year_of_birth, race_concept_id,
#>   ethnicity_concept_id
#> â€¢ observation_period: observation_period_id, person_id,

    Export the cdm reference

    When the export method is applied to a cdm reference, metadata about that cdm will be written to a csv. The csv contains the following columns

    Variable Description
    result_type
    cdm_name
    cdm_source_name
    cdm_description
    cdm_documentation_reference
    cdm_version
    cdm_holder
    cdm_release_date
    vocabulary_version
    person_count
    observation_period_count
    earliest_observation_period_start_date
    latest_observation_period_end_date
    snapshot_date

    export method â€¦.
